{{Other people|Stephen Ross}} {{Infobox person | name = Stephen M. Ross | image = Stephen M. Ross.jpg | imagesize = 200 px | caption = Ross at an event at [[Miami Beach Senior High]] | nationality = United States | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1940|5|10|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], U.S. | residence = [[New York, New York]], U.S.
[[Palm Beach, Florida]], U.S. | known_for = [[Time Warner Center]] | alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] (BS)
[[Wayne State University]] (JD)
[[New York University]] (LLM) | occupation = Chairman of [[The Related Companies]],
95% owner of [[Miami Dolphins]] | spouse = [[Kara Ross|Kara Gaffney]] | children = 4 | networth = US$ 7.6 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] (June 2018){{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/stephen-ross/|title=Forbes profile: Stephen Ross|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=22 June 2018}} | relations = [[Max Fisher]] (uncle) }} '''Stephen M. Ross''' (born May 10, 1940) is an American [[real estate developer]], philanthropist and [[List of NFL franchise owners|sports team owner]]. Ross is the chairman and majority owner of [[The Related Companies]], a global real estate development firm he founded in 1972. Related is best known for developing the [[Time Warner Center]], where Ross lives and works, as well as the [[Hudson Yards Redevelopment Project]]. According to ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine, Ross had a [[net worth]] of $4.4 billion.Kellie Woodhouse, [http://www.annarbor.com/news/umich-donation-ross/ Stephen M. Ross gives University of Michigan record $200M] (September 4, 2013), AnnArbor.com. Ross is also the principal owner of the [[Miami Dolphins]] and [[Hard Rock Stadium]].[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/football/nfl/01/20/dolphins.ap/index.html Stephen Ross Buys Ownership of the Miami Dolphins] SI.com, January 20, 2009 Ross is a major benefactor of his alma mater, the [[University of Michigan]]; with lifetime contributions of $378 million to the university, he is the largest donor in [[History of the University of Michigan|university history]].David Jesse, [http://www.freep.com/article/20130904/NEWS06/309040064/U-M-receives-record-setting-200-million-donation U-M receives record-setting $200-million donation from Stephen Ross], ''Detroit Free Press'' (September 4, 2013). According to the ''[[Chronicle of Philanthropy]]'', His [[higher education]] gifts rank behind only those of fellow American billionaire [[Mayor of New York City|New York City mayor]] [[Michael Bloomberg]], whose recent $350 million contribution to [[Johns Hopkins University]] increased his lifetime total to $1.1 billion.[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/27/nyregion/at-1-1-billion-bloomberg-is-top-university-donor-in-us.html?_r=1& $1.1 Billion in Thanks From Bloomberg to Johns Hopkins]. Retrieved on 2013-11-12. The University of Michigan renamed its business school, the [[Ross School of Business]], in Ross's honor in 2004, after he made a $100 million gift to fund a new business-school building.[http://www.bus.umich.edu/RossB-SchoolGift/gift/name-change/ Why Change the Name of the School? | Stephen M. Ross – University of Michigan Business School]. Retrieved on 2012-03-22.[http://www.bus.umich.edu/RossB-SchoolGift/gift/ About the Gift | Stephen M. Ross – University of Michigan Business School]. Bus.umich.edu. Retrieved on 2012-03-22. In September 2013, Ross donated $200 million to the University ($100 million to the Business School and $100 million to [[Michigan Wolverines|Michigan athletics]]), the largest single gift in the history of the university; the University of Michigan announced plans to rename the university's athletics campus in his honor. He also gave $5 million to the athletic department's academic center and $1 million to endow a professorship in real estate at the Ross School of Business. ==Early life and education== Ross was raised in a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family[http://www.davidovit.com/articles/Ross.pdf "Stephen M. Ross" BY ALIZA DAVIDOVIT] retrieved October 25, 2012[http://forward.com/articles/152696/romney-pac-attracts-new-jewish-donors/?p=all The Jewish Daily Forward: "Romney PAC Attracts New Jewish Donors: Hedge Fund Managers and Developers Top List of Supporters" by Josh Nathan-Kazis] March 12, 2012[http://www.thejewishweek.com/blogs/gary_rosenblatt/billionaires_busy_praying The New York Jewish Week: "Billionaires Busy Praying?" by Gary Rosenblatt] August 23, 2008 in [[Detroit]], where he went to [[Mumford High School]],{{cite news|last1=Murray|first1=Tom|title=Family Ties: Stephen M. Ross parlayed two family loans into a multibillion-dollar enterprise|url=http://www.dbusiness.com/March-April-2015/Family-Ties/|accessdate=10 October 2015|work=dbusiness|date=June 4, 2015}} and later graduated from [[Miami Beach Senior High School]]. He attended the [[University of Florida]] and then transferred to the [[University of Michigan Business School]], where he earned his B.S. degree in accounting in 1962. He later received a [[Juris Doctor]] from the [[Wayne State University|Wayne State School of Law]] in 1965 and an [[LL.M.]] degree in Taxation from the [[New York University School of Law]] in 1966.[http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3847012 Ross becomes owner of the Dolphins]. Sports.espn.go.com (2009-01-21). Retrieved on 2012-03-22. These later degrees were financed by a loan from his uncle, the businessman [[Max Fisher]], who Ross has called, "the most important role model and inspiration for me in life".{{cite web|title=Ross’ connections with Michigan|url=https://michiganross.umich.edu/news/ross%E2%80%99-connections-michigan|website=michiganross|accessdate=10 October 2015}} ==Career== Ross began his career as a tax attorney at [[Coopers & Lybrand]] in [[Detroit]]. In 1968, he moved to New York City and accepted a position as an assistant vice president in the real estate subsidiary of [[G. H. Walker & Co.|Laird Inc.]] and then worked in the corporate finance department of [[Bear Stearns]]. In 1972, he left employment and living off $10,000 lent to him by his mother,[http://www.bus.umich.edu/NewsRoom/BusinessSchoolPubs/DividendAlumniMagazine/Fall_2004/StephenMRoss.pdf University of Michigan: "Two Men, One Vision - With $100 Million Gift, Steve Ross] Retrieved March 23, 2013 he utilized his federal tax law knowledge to organize deals for wealthy investors allowing them to shelter income with the generous incentives granted by the federal government to promote the construction of federally subsidized affordable housing. He was very successful, earning $150,000 in his first year, and he was soon arranging more complicated transactions. Using his earnings along with his newfound experience, he started to develop real estate on his own and with an emphasis on high-quality architecture and engineering, he quickly earned a solid reputation in the American real estate arena. With a focus on the northeastern United States and Florida, he developed apartments, condominiums, retail, office parks and mixed-use developments. In 1972, he founded [[The Related Companies]], a real estate development company.{{cite web|title=Stephen M. Ross J.D.|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=385782&privcapId=6628350&previousCapId=249841&previousTitle=HESS%20CORP|publisher=Bloomberg Newsweek|accessdate=8 November 2013}} ===The Related Companies=== Related is an integrated and diversified real estate development company. Its business includes development, acquisitions, management, finance, marketing and sales. Headquartered in New York City, Related has offices and real estate developments in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, Las Vegas, San Francisco, South Florida, Abu Dhabi, and Shanghai. The company directly employs approximately 2,000 people.{{cite web|title=STEPHEN M. ROSS Chairman and Founder Related Companies|url=http://www.related.com/our-company/executives/1/STEPHEN-M-ROSS|accessdate=8 November 2013}} The company's existing portfolio of real estate assets, valued at over $15 billion, is made up of mixed-use, residential, retail, office, trade show and affordable properties in what the company calls "premier high-barrier-to-entry markets." Related is the largest owner of luxury residential rental properties in New York with over 5,000 units in its portfolio and has developed mixed-use projects such as Time Warner Center in New York and CityPlace in West Palm Beach and is currently developing the 26-acre [[Hudson Yards (development)|Hudson Yards project]][http://therealdeal.com/blog/2013/08/16/anatomy-of-a-deal-inside-relatedoxfords-unusual-hudson-yards-financing/ Anatomy of a deal: Inside Related/Oxford’s unusual financing of Hudson Yards]" ''The Real Deal ''(August 13, 2013) on Manhattan's west side.{{cite news|title=Stephen Ross: The Billionaire Who Is Rebuilding New York|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/morganbrennan/2012/03/07/stephen-ross-the-billionaire-who-is-rebuilding-new-york/ | work=Forbes | first=Morgan | last=Brennan | date=2012-03-07}} Related also manages approximately $1.5 billion of equity capital on behalf of sovereign wealth funds, public pension plans, multi-managers, endowments, [[Taft-Hartley]] plans and family offices.{{Cite news| url =http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/538a7a72-438c-11e1-9f28-00144feab49a.html#axzz1kIdU0pmu |title= Related closes distressed asset fund|author= Anjli Raval|publisher=[[Financial Times]] |date =January 23, 2012}} Related also owns [[Equinox Fitness]] Clubs and a partnership interest in Union Square Events, the catering, culture, sports, and events business of [[Danny Meyer]]'s [[Union Square Hospitality Group]]. ===Miami Dolphins=== In February 2008, Ross bought 50 percent of the Miami Dolphin franchise, Dolphin Stadium (now known as Hard Rock Stadium) and surrounding land from then-owner [[Wayne Huizenga]] for $550 million, with an agreement to later become the Dolphins' managing general partner. On January 20, 2009, Ross closed on the purchase of an additional 45% of the team from Wayne Huizenga. The total value of the deal was $1.1 billion.{{cite web|url=http://cbs4.com/sports/Stephen.Ross.dolphins.2.913395.html |title=Ross Becomes Miami Dolphins Majority Owner |publisher=CBS |date=2009-01-20 |accessdate=2010-04-03}}{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3847012 |title=Ross, Huizenga complete Fins sale |agency=Associated Press |publisher=ESPN |date=2009-01-21 |accessdate=2010-04-03}} This means Ross is now the owner of 95% of both the franchise and the stadium. Ross announced his intention to keep [[Bill Parcells]] as the director of football operations. Parcells later stepped down from his position shortly before the 2010 NFL season. Since buying the Dolphins, Ross has brought in [[Gloria Estefan]], [[Marc Anthony]], [[Venus Williams]], and [[Serena Williams]], as minority owners of the team. In 2013, Ross made a push to obtain multimillion-dollar public funding from the state of Florida and Miami-Dade taxpayers to help renovate Hard Rock Stadium, the Dolphins' home field. After this effort failed in the Florida legislature, a team spokesman said that Ross does not intend to move the team but that under an eventual future owner the Dolphins' future in the Miami area is bleak.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/9246386/miami-dolphins-pay-stadium-fixes-ceo-mike-dee |title=Fins Future in Miami Bleak |publisher=ESPN |date=2013-05-06 |accessdate=2013-05-06}} Although Ross said he intends to keep the Dolphins "in town", there has been speculation that the team may seek to move out of Miami to a nearby locale such as Palm Beach.{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/05/10/3389294/miami-dolphins-open-minded-to.html |title=Dolphins Open to Stadium in Palm Beach |work=The Miami Herald |date=2013-05-09 |accessdate=2013-05-10}}{{cite news|url=http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/riptide/2013/05/roger_goodell_we_want_dolphins.php |title=Roger Goodell: 'We Want Dolphins to Stay in Miami{{'-}} |work=Miami New Times |date=2013-05-10 |accessdate=2013-05-10}} ===RSE Ventures=== RSE Ventures is a private investment firm that focuses on sports and entertainment, media and marketing, food and lifestyle, and technology. RSE Ventures was co-founded in 2012 by Ross and [[Matt Higgins (businessman)]], former Executive Vice President of the [[New York Jets]]{{Cite news| url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203753704577253943817749620/|title=Ex-Jets Executive Joins Miami Owner's Venture|author= Matthew Futterman|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date = February 29, 2012}} and current Vice Chairman of the Miami Dolphins.{{Cite news| url =http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/sports/football/young-and-influential-dolphins-fans-know-little-of/nccD4/ |title=Young and influential: Miami Dolphins fans know little of Matt Higgins, key adviser to owner Stephen Ross|author=Andrew Abramson|publisher=The Palm Beach Post|date = January 4, 2014}} RSE builds, owns and operates a variety of companies, including the [[Drone Racing League]], [[Thuzio]], VaynerMedia and Relevent.{{Cite news| url =https://www.forbes.com/sites/jasonbelzer/2014/07/24/how-rse-ventures-is-revolutionizing-business-as-we-know-it/ |title= How RSE Ventures Is Revolutionizing Business As We Know It|author=Jason Belzer |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date = July 24, 2014}}{{Cite news| url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/developer-stephen-rosss-rse-ventures-invests-in-drone-racing-1439327632 |title= Developer Stephen Ross’s RSE Ventures Invests in Drone Racing |author= Emily Nonko |publisher=Wall Street Journal |date = August 12, 2015}}{{Cite news| url =https://ny.eater.com/2016/12/13/13935054/david-chang-investor-rse|title=Momofuku Gets a New Investor, Vaucluse Adds a Bar Menu, and More Intel |author=Greg Morabito |publisher=[[Eater.com]] |date = December 13, 2016}} === Kangaroo Media/FanVision === Ross and [[Carl Peterson]] own Kangaroo Media, producer of FanVision.{{cite news | last =Nixon | first =Alex | title =Kangaroo Media sues YinzCam over patents | newspaper = ''[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]'' | date =March 29, 2012 | url =http://triblive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/business/s_788817.html | accessdate = January 11, 2014}} ==Civic and philanthropic activities== Ross was co-chair of the [[University of Michigan]]'s fund raising campaign, which was completed May 2007. In 2004, Ross made the single largest contribution (at the time) to the University of Michigan by donating $100 million to the school. The University renamed its business school, [[Ross School of Business]] in his honor. On September 12, 2013, it was announced Ross had committed an additional $200 million gift to the University, to be distributed equally among the Ross School of Business and the University's athletic department. It replaced [[Charlie Munger]]'s 2013 contribution of $115 million as the largest single gift in the University's history.{{cite web|title=Stephen Ross tosses University of Michigan $200 million donation|url=http://www.heritage.com/articles/2013/09/12/ann_arbor_journal/news/doc52308a3edd1eb346969898.txt|publisher=Ann Arbor Journal|accessdate=13 September 2013}}. On September 20, 2017, Ross donated an additional 50 million to the University of Michigan, the majority of which would support career development programs for students, innovative action-based learning experiences, and resources for attracting and developing junior faculty.{{cite news|last1=Guest|first1=Greta|title=Stephen Ross gives additional $50 million to U-M, bringing total lifetime giving to $378 million|url=http://ns.umich.edu/new/releases/25095-stephen-ross-gives-additional-50-million-to-u-m-bringing-total-lifetime-giving-to-378-million|accessdate=20 September 2017|publisher=University of Michigan News|date=20 September 2017}} He was on the executive committee of NYC2012, New York's initiative to bring the summer Olympic Games to New York City in 2012, which failed when London won. Ross is chairman of Equinox Holdings, and chairperson emeritus of the [[Real Estate Board of New York]] (REBNY), the city's leading real estate trade association. As a member of the board of trustees of the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation]], Ross was involved in the planning of a major renovation of the [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] iconic building and other new museums. He is a trustee of [[New York Presbyterian Hospital]], the [[Urban Land Institute]], the NY Chapter of [[Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International]], the [[Levin Institute]] and is a director of the [[Jackie Robinson Foundation]] and the [[World Resources Institute]].[[World Resources Institute]] [http://www.wri.org/about/board/stephen-ross Biosketch of Stephen M. Ross]. Accessed March 27, 2012. He also serves on the Executive Committee and is a trustee of [[Lincoln Center]]. Ross was a major supporter and contributor to the 2012 presidential campaign of [[Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012|Mitt Romney]].[https://www.forbes.com/sites/lauriebennett/2012/02/01/billionaires-give-2-million-to-romney-super-pac/ Forbes: "Billionaires Give $2 Million to Romney Super PAC" by Laurie Bennett] February 1, 2012 He serves on the Board for the [[Cornell Tech]] Campus,{{Cite web|url=https://tech.cornell.edu/people/board-of-overseers|title=Board of Overseers|website=Cornell Tech|language=en|access-date=2017-05-17}} a $2B redevelopment of Roosevelt Island including the Joan & Irwin Jacobs Technion-Cornell Institute, a partnership between [[Cornell University]] and the [[Technion – Israel Institute of Technology]] that when completed will house several thousand post-graduate students, hundreds of faculty, and a high-tech business incubator.{{Cite web|url=https://ny.curbed.com/2016/3/2/11147898/tech-hub-the-bridge-tops-out-at-cornell-roosevelt-island-campus|title=Tech Incubator at Cornell's Roosevelt Island Campus Tops Out|date=2016-03-02|website=Curbed NY|access-date=2017-05-17}} On March 27, 2017, Ross cast the only "no" vote in the NFL owners' 31–1 "yes" decision on the [[Oakland Raiders]] request for approval to move to Las Vegas starting in the 2019 season. Ross said he had no personal problems with Raiders owner [[Mark Davis (American football)|Mark Davis]] and wished the franchise well, but did not think the Raiders did everything they could to stay in Oakland, and also that having 3 teams move within only 15 months (the Rams and Chargers both moved to Los Angeles) was not good for players or fans. Ross also stated prior to his Dolphins playing the Chargers in their first home game since the move to Los Angeles that he did not believe that Chargers owner Dean Spanos made his best effort to stay in San Diego, making him a popular figure with the betrayed San Diego fan base. Ross invested in a partnership named RERI that was donated to the University of Michigan in 2003. RERI obtained its own appraisal for the donation in the amount of $32,935,000. The university sold the Ross-donated remainder interest in December, 2005 for $1.94 million, below the $6.5 million appraised value. The IRS denied the entire $33 million tax deduction and imposed a multi million dollar penalty in July, 2017. Ross's long time accountant Alan Katz and business associate, Harold Levine were instrumental in the partnership. They are currently under criminal investigation for the tax plan.{{cite news|last1=Dolan|first1=Matthew|url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2017/08/27/stephen-ross-tax-break-gift-michigan/563170001/|accessdate=27 August 2017|agency=Detroit Free Press}} ==Honors and awards== Over the years, Ross has received numerous honors for his business, civic, and philanthropic activities. He was named the third Most Powerful Person in New York Real Estate by the New York Observer, Multi-Family Property Executive of the Year by Commercial Property News, and Housing Person of the Year by the National Housing Conference.{{cite web|title=The 100 Most Powerful People in New York Real Estate|url=http://www.naftaligroup.com/press/Ivanhoe-Observer.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213173452/http://www.naftaligroup.com/press/Ivanhoe-Observer.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=December 13, 2013|publisher=Jared Kushner|accessdate=February 12, 2013}} He also received The National Building Museum Honor Award, REBNY's Harry B. Helmsley Distinguished New Yorker Award and the [[Jack D. Weiler]] Award from UJA. Crain's New York named Ross one of the 100 Most Influential Leaders in Business and he was recognized by NYC & Company with their Leadership in Tourism Award. ==Personal life== Ross and his wife [[Kara Ross]] (née Gaffney),O'Halloran, Caroline (March 18, 2011). [https://archive.is/20130411071537/http://www.mainlinemedianews.com/articles/2011/03/18/people/flair/doc4d83eb6e138c9433680449.txt?viewmode=fullstory "Rock star ascending: Main Line-bred jewelry maker Kara Ross"]. Main Line Media News. an entrepreneur and [[jewelry designer]],[http://www.bus.umich.edu/RossB-SchoolGift/donor/ University of Michigan – Stephen M. Ross] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514060000/http://www.bus.umich.edu/RossB-SchoolGift/donor/ |date=2013-05-14 }}.[http://www.kararossny.com/index.php?&storeid=45&page=about&sess=store45 Kara Ross website: Biography] retrieved March 23, 2013 reside in New York with her two daughters from a previous marriage.[https://archive.is/20130411071537/http://www.mainlinemedianews.com/articles/2011/03/18/people/flair/doc4d83eb6e138c9433680449.txt?viewmode=fullstory Main Line media news: "Rock star ascending: Main Line-bred jewelry maker Kara Ross" By Caroline O'Halloran] March 18, 2011 Ross has two of his own children from his first marriage. The Rosses also own an 11,000 sq ft oceanfront mansion in [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]] named "The Reef".https://www.curbed.com/2013/5/8/10245692/stephen-m-ross-the-reef-palm-beach#2 ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.miamidolphins.com/team/staff/steven-ross/f0a28e3e-5ff7-409e-bc14-48c9b3f978bd Stephen M. Ross – Chairman Of The Board] * [http://therealdeal.com/blog/2013/08/16/anatomy-of-a-deal-inside-relatedoxfords-unusual-hudson-yards-financing/ Anatomy of a deal: Inside Related/Oxford’s unusual financing of Hudson Yards] *[https://www.google.com/search?q=Stephen+M.+Ross+images&hl=en&prmd=imvnso&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=A8_OTqfBFMifgwePlu2oDQ&ved=0CCwQsAQ&biw=1602&bih=735&sei=Ds_OTp3PHYX7ggfFuvjXDQ Images for Stephen M. Ross], [https://www.google.com google.com] {{Miami Dolphins}} {{DolphinsOwner}} {{NFLOwners}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ross, Stephen M.}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:American chairmen of corporations]] [[Category:American company founders]] [[Category:American marketing businesspeople]] [[Category:American political fundraisers]] [[Category:American real estate businesspeople]] [[Category:American sports businesspeople]] [[Category:Bear Stearns people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]] [[Category:Giving Pledgers]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Jewish American sportspeople]] [[Category:Miami Beach Senior High School alumni]] [[Category:Miami Dolphins owners]] [[Category:Michigan lawyers]] [[Category:Michigan Republicans]] [[Category:New York Islanders]] [[Category:New York (state) Republicans]] [[Category:New York University School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Patrons of schools]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Detroit]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Real estate company founders]] [[Category:Ross School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Solomon R. revision.text:
The '''Swedish Chronicle''' (''Vetus chronicon sveciæ prosaicum'' or ''Prosaiska krönikan'') is a mid-15th century chronicle on a nation called [[Getae]] (''gethe''), [[Goths]] (''gotha''), [[Geat]]s (''götha'') and eventually Swedes (''swenske''). It says that it is compiled from ancient chronicles.
It includes a line of kings from the House of [[Yngling]] which appears to be based on the Norwegian ''[[Historia Norwegiæ]]'' and the Danish ''[[Chronicon Lethrense]]'', but the compiler seems to have ''corrected'' the information.
The first part of its line of Swedish kings: *Inge ([[Yngvi]], here the son of [[Filimer]]) *Neorch and Froe ([[Njord]] and [[Freyr]]) *Urbar (made his son [[Dan (king)|Dan]] king of Denmark and his son Nore the king of Norway) *Östen *Solen (was drowned in a vat of mead like [[Fjölnir]]) *Swerker *[[Valand]] *Wisbur *Domalde (was sacrificed to a troll named Ceres) *Domar *Attila (made the Danes accept the [[dog king]] as their king) *Dyguer *Dager *Alrik (was killed by his brother Erik with a rein) *Ingemar (was hanged by his wife in [[Agnafit]]) *Ingeller (was killed by his own brother) *Järunder *Hakon (killed [[Harald Wartooth]] at the [[Battle of Brávellir]] and became so old that he had to feed by suckling a horn) *Eghil *Oktar (killed by his brother Faste) *Adhel (died when he fell off his horse during the sacrifices) *Östen (was arsoned to death) *Ingemar *Bräntemundher (was killed by his own brother Sigurd in Närke) *Ingeller (was so afraid of Ivar the far-travelled that he arsoned himself to death) *Olaffver trätelge *Inge (died in battle) *[[Erik Weatherhat]] *[[Eric the Victorious]] *Stenkil of Good Harvests (the first Christian king) *[[Olof Skötkonung]]
...
==Sources and external links== *[http://www.nordlund.lu.se/Fornsvenska/Fsv%20Folder/05_Filer/Proskron.rtf The Swedish Chronicle, in the original language (rtf)]. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061025234816/http://www.carlaz.com/phd/cea_phd_chap5.pdf Anderson, Carl Edlund. ''Formation and Resolution of Ideological Contrast in the Early History of Scandinavia''. Ph.D. thesis, University of Cambridge, Department of Anglo-Saxon, Norse & Celtic (Faculty of English)]
{{Sweden-hist-stub}}
